title: What are the best scientific papers? - Quora

response.answer_text: One of the most influential papers published in the last decade or so is undoubtedly Bitcoin: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System by Satoshi Nakamoto, link here: https://bitcoin.org/bitcoin.pdf However, there are many more interesting and inspiring papers out there that cover a broader range of scientific topics. I recommend going to the following website: Home :: SSRN. From that page, you can browse the Top Papers in Rankings, and you’ll get a more curated list of what a large amount of people consider to be some of the best recent scientific work out there.

CIA website has release 3 million government files ,projects. From mind control to UFO tech to the tech we have know. It's a big part of history now anyone is allowed to research with now hassal .that it's been doing over the decades feel free to read the first file as I did and to me it was astonishing to see what was going on on our planet it's mind-blowing so feel free to check it out .the questions you thrive to know are all in there there's enough to go around just don't take you in what your mind can't handle how far will science take you just what ever you do don't watch videos you have to research the videos sepretly. It's been open to public on the website for months and I bet you anything a lot of you scientists haven't even took the time to even research one thing to do with that so how can you call yourselves scientists if you don't explore the nature of science

Hard question to answer, but Stephen Muggleton's paper Learning from Positive Data made a big impression on me - http://www.doc.ic.ac.uk/~shm/Papers/poslearn1.ps.gz In general I usually prefer papers in ACM Computing Surveys which have overview articles which are sufficiently narrow that are are useful before you dive into more specific papers (perhaps through the bibliography of the survey paper), e.g. in the March 2010 issue there is a good paper - Location-dependent query processing: Where we are and where we are heading - http://bit.ly/aMoo2I
Claude Shannon's "A Mathematical Theory of Communications" http://cm.bell-labs.com/cm/ms/what/shannonday/paper.html

I’m a huge fan of Alan Turing’s work! This particular paper - https://www.csee.umbc.edu/courses/471/papers/turing.pdf - was one of the best things I’d read. I came across it a couple of years ago, and what really impressed me was the simplicity with which he conveyed his ideas. I’m not saying it is very vigorous, but it’s definitely an eye-opener to amateurs. I was in 8th grade when I read it and…it was beautiful! Definitely worth a read!

I'd be very hard pressed to find a set of papers that can beat these two: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1311997/pdf/jaba00061-0143a.pdf http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2078566/pdf/jaba-40-04-773.pdf

John Nash's "Equilibrium Points in N-Person Games", published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, January 1950. In 333 words, Nash, (21-year-old graduate student at Princeton), defined the main rule of game theory: the Nash equilibrium.

“EPR”: Einstein, A; B Podolsky; N Rosen (1935-05-15). "Can Quantum-Mechanical Description of Physical Reality be Considered Complete?" Can Quantum-Mechanical Description of Physical Reality Be Considered Complete?

Watson and Crick's first paper describing the DNAhttp://www.nature.com/nature/dna50/watsoncrick.pdf  Any of the first papers by Einsteinhttp://www.casavaria.com/hotspring/2008/05/21/123/einsteins-special-theory-of-relativity-the-original-paper-1905/  http://www.fourmilab.ch/etexts/einstein/specrel/www/
